c74object.name: bach.graph
c74object.description: The purpose of bach.graph is to act as a simple graph plotter: once the expression of the curve to draw has been set (in the first inlet) possibly along with its parameters (in the second inlet), a bang will plot the curve. Vector representation are also possible.

inlet.digest: Set formulas or bang to plot graph
All the parameters of the inserted formulas
inlet.description: The second inlet expects all the parameters of the formula

outlet.digest: Dumped interleaved list of X Y couples
bang when user changes the graph with the mouse

method.name: (mouse)
method.description:
With the Cartesian Points or Polar Points types of graph (see graphtype attribute):
• click+drag: If clicked on an existing point, moves the point
• Alt+click: Adds a new point
• Cmd+click (mac) or Ctrl+click (win): On an existing point, deletes the point
and its two new coordinates X and Y. All these command work provided that the graph is a Cartesian Points or Polar Points type of graph, see graphtype attribute.

method.name: add
method.description:
Syntax: add <number: x_coord> <number: y_coord>
Example: add 3 4 → add a point at x=3, y=4
The word add followed by two coordinates X and Y will add a point on the graph with such coordinates (provided that the graph is a Cartesian Points or Polar Points type of graph, see graphtype attribute).
See also:remove,set

method.name: clear
method.description: Removes the displayed function from the graph.

method.name: dump
method.description:
The dump message outputs from bach.graph's outlet the points of the graph in an interlaced list of X values and Y values such as 0. 0. 0.338538 1.91993 -7.327899 2.667156 -8.773019 -15.195196.... If you want to isolate couples, use bach.group with 2 as argument, which will get you to the form (0. 0.) (0.338538 1.91993) (-7.327899 2.667156) (-8.773019 -15.195196)... where each X Y couple is wrapped.
The output points are the sampling that bach.graph does according to all the values of its attributes, except for the Cartesian Points or Polar Points graph (see graphtype attribute), for which the output points are the ones explicitely added by the user

method.name: exprr
method.description:
Syntax: exprr <llll: expression>
In polar mode (see graphtype attribute), you can define the expression for the radius R with respect to the angle Theta, such as R = f(Theta), with Theta being the independent variable (angle in radians). After the exprr symbol, a formula in bach.expr style is expected. The free variable Theta is represented by $f1. For instance, a valid expression can be exprr $f1*$f1.
See also:exprx,expry,bang

method.name: exprx
method.description:
Syntax: exprx <llll: expression>
In parametric mode (see graphtype attribute) you can define separately the expressions for the X and Y variables. Via exprx one defines the formula for the X variable, as X = f(T), where T is the independent variable. After the exprx symbol, a formula in bach.expr style is expected. The free variable T is represented by $f1. For instance, a valid expression can be exprx sin($f1+cos($f1)+$f2), where $f2 is a parameter whose value has to be input from the right inlet.
See also:expry,exprr,bang

method.name: expry
method.description:
Syntax: expry <llll: expression>
Via expry one defines the formula for the Y variable, either as Y = f(X), in cartesian mode, or as Y = f(T), in parametric mode (see graphtype attribute), where X and T are the indepentent variables. After the expry symbol, a formula in bach.expr style is expected. The free variable X or T is represented by $f1. For instance, a valid expression can be expry sin($f1*$f1+$f2)+$f3, where $f2 and $f3 are parameters whose values have to be input from the right inlet.
See also:exprx,exprr,bang

method.name: list
method.description: Plot the graph of the most recently input equation, with the most recently input values of parameters.

method.name: llll
method.description: A plain llll in the second inlet will set the values for all the parameters of the introduced equation. Parameters correspond to all variables starting from $f2 onwards. So first element of this list will correspond to $f2, second element to $f3, and so on. If there are no free parameters in the equation, this inlet is useless. You can input elements as integers, floats or rational numbers, and then let bach.graph convert them to floats.

method.name: remove
method.description:
Syntax: remove <int: point-index>
Example: remove 4 → remove 4th introduced point
To delete a point on the graph, send the word remove followed by the index of the point to be removed. For instance, remove 1 will remove the first introduced point.
See also:add,set

method.name: set
method.digest: Change the position of a point
method.description:
Syntax: set <int: point-index> <llllelem: X-coordinate> <llllelem: Y-coordinate>
Example: set 1 4 5 → set 1st introduced point at x=4, y=5
To change the position of a point, send the word set followed by the index of the point to be moved and its two new coordinates X and Y. This works provided that the graph is a Cartesian Points or Polar Points type of graph, see graphtype attribute. For instance, set 2 0 1 sets the second point to have cartesian coordinates (0 1).
See also:add,remove

method.name: setclick
method.description:
Syntax: setclick <int: point-index>
Example: click 5 → simulate clicking on 5th introduced point
For Cartesian Points or Polar Points type of graph, clicks on a given point and triggers the following output (exactly as via mouse interaction).
See also:setclick

method.name: setclick
method.digest: Set the clicked point without triggering any output
method.description:
Syntax: setclick <int: point-index>
Example: setclick 5 → set 5th introduced point as clicked
For Cartesian Points or Polar Points type of graph, sets the currently clicked point without triggering any output.
See also:click

attribute.name: axiscolor
attribute.description: Sets the color for the axis.

attribute.name: bgcolor
attribute.description: Sets the graph background color.

attribute.name: bordercolor
attribute.description: Sets the graph border color.

attribute.name: clickedcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of the clicked points (in Cartesian or Polar Points mode only).

attribute.name: embed
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to embed the graph as a part of the patch, when this latter is saved. The default behaviour is 1 (graph is saved).

attribute.name: graphcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of the graph line.

attribute.name: graphtype
attribute.description:
Specifies the type of graph:
Cartesian: A standard X = f(Y) cartesian graph
Polar: A graph in the form R = f(Theta), with R radius and Theta angle in radians
Parametric: A graph defined by X = f(T) and Y = g(T), with T being the indipendent "time" variable
Cartesian Points: A cartesian graph, but where the user inserts the points one by one, instead of the function formula
Polar Points: A polar graph, but where the user inserts the points one by one, instead of the function formula

attribute.name: gridcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color of the graph grid.

attribute.name: gridrstep
attribute.description: Sets the distance between two concentric grid circles for polar types of graph (see graphtype attribute).

attribute.name: gridthetastep
attribute.description: Sets the angle distance (in radians) between two grid directions starting from the origin for polar types of graph (see graphtype attribute).

attribute.name: gridtype
attribute.description:
Sets the grid type:
None: No grid is displayed
Ticks: Ticks are displayed on the axis (and possibly on the unit circle)
Lattice: The grid lines are properly displayed

attribute.name: gridxstep
attribute.description: Sets the horizontal distance between two grid lines on the X axis.

attribute.name: gridystep
attribute.description: Sets the horizontal distance between two grid lines on the Y axis.

attribute.name: labelsxstep
attribute.description: Sets the distance between two consecutive labels on the X axis.

attribute.name: labelsystep
attribute.description: Sets the distance between two consecutive labels on the Y axis.

attribute.name: linewidth
attribute.description: Sets the width of the graph line.

attribute.name: maxt
attribute.description: For parametric graphs (see graphtype attribute), sets the maximum sampled T value.

attribute.name: maxtheta
attribute.description: For polar graphs (see graphtype attribute), sets the maximum sampled Theta value.

attribute.name: maxx
attribute.description: Sets the maximum displayed X on the graph. For cartesian graphs (see graphtype attribute), this is also the maximum sampled X value.

attribute.name: maxy
attribute.description: Sets the maximum displayed Y on the graph.

attribute.name: mint
attribute.description: For parametric graphs (see graphtype attribute), sets the minimum sampled T value.

attribute.name: mintheta
attribute.description: For polar graphs (see graphtype attribute), sets the maximum sampled Theta value.

attribute.name: minx
attribute.description: Sets the minimum displayed X on the graph. For cartesian graphs (see graphtype attribute), this is also the minimum sampled X value.

attribute.name: miny
attribute.description: Sets the minimum displayed Y on the graph.

attribute.name: modify
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to allow modifications the graph points (only in Cartesian Points or Polar Points mode).

attribute.name: mousehover
attribute.description: Toggles the ability to mouse hover on function slot points (only in Cartesian Points or Polar Points mode).

attribute.name: numpoints
attribute.description: Number of points in which the equation is sampled (cannot exceed 1000). The boundaries for this sampling are given by the various minx, maxx, mint, maxt, mintheta, maxtheta attributes.

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the following:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message. To keep the representation invertible (i.e., to allow a bach object receiving a text-format llll to interpret it exactly as if it was native format, except for the size limitation), some specific kinds of symbols are preceded by a backtick: namely, symbols containing parens, or containing textual representations of numbers or pitches, or beginning with a backtick, plus the symbols "null" and "nil" (distinct from the reserved words "null" and "nil" representing the empty list and the empty sublist) are preceded by a backtick. Moreover, the symbols "int", "float" or "list" are preceded by a backtick only if they are the first element of an llll, to distinguish them from the corresponding reserved messages of Max.
m: 'max' output: mostly equivalent to the "t" specifier, but no symbol is backticket except "int", "float" and "list" at the beginning of an llll. It is important to notice that, differently from text-format lllls proper, Max-format lllls might not be invertible even if they do not reach the size limit for Max message. This means that a bach object receiving a Max-format llll output from another bach object might interpret it differently from the original, or in some cases might even reject it.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.

attribute.name: pointradius
attribute.description: Sets the radius for each point on the graph (see showmode attribute).

attribute.name: showclicked
attribute.description: Shows the clicked point via a special color circle (only for Cartesian or Polar Points mode).

attribute.name: showlabels
attribute.description: Toggles the view of the grid labels.

attribute.name: showmode
attribute.description:
Sets the display mode for the graph:
Line: A simple line shows the graph function
Points: Points are drawn at the sampled locations, and no line is shown
Line And Points: Both the line and the points are shown
Vectors: Points in the graph are considered to be vectors and drawn with arrows starting from the origin.

attribute.name: showunitcircle
attribute.description: Toggles the view of the unit circle.

attribute.name: showxyaxis
attribute.description: Toggles the view of the X and Y axis.

attribute.name: showxylabels
attribute.description: Toggles the view of the X and Y axis labels.

attribute.name: textcolor
attribute.description: Sets the color for the labels on the axis.
